								As a person who did boxing as a hobby in college, I am very happy with this game and defintiely recommend it (especially because it is not a wave shooter like the rest of the VR games out there). I can block, bob and weave, counter punch when the computer throws punches (uppercuts, cross, hooks), so it's a great alternative to shadowboxing because you can practice defense at the same time. The blocking stamina mechanic is a good compromise so people dont cheese the system. However, since it is an early access game it is low on content (only one practice opponent and one real opponent), but I am sure the developer will add more soon since he has been very receptive to feedback and quick with his updates since his demo. The core mechanics are very solid and it is definitely worth the current price.   EDIT: Adding a gameplay video of myself to give people an idea of what to expect.

								Tried out the Beta and still enjoyed the game. The added arms gives you advantage to block attacks, I like the new damage system being reduced when you partially block an attack, even using your arms. I was amazed how close to accurate your arms are at, though it needs some work according to the developer but I trust him based from my experience, it looks like it is heading to the right direction. Always remember to let the game calibrate your body to get proper proportions, also calibrate each time you switch the vive to another friend. Heavy punching opponents (There is a new guy who is like a heavy weight with heavy punches) are tougher to block, sometimes it requires 2 hands to block heavy shots and blocking using 1 arm/glove sometimes is not enough. Your arms and the opponents arms react like that of the game Fight Night series where it can tangle at some point but not to an extent and sill feels like arcade. The damage you can give now is based off the speed of your punch, it gets challenging and pushes your strength specially when you are already tired at some point. Early releases feels more arcade, this one still is but with a bit of realism, punches do not fully go through their heads depending on the strength of punch, it can still go through their bodies but sometimes it stops at some point, your arms/gloves might not be where they are but they are just only inches off and I like the feel and most of the time it is on point. Some might not like it, but I guess because it feels different, for those who haven't tried the game yet and go straight to beta, you will still enjoy even with the new changes, they have their equal ups and downs, it is still the same game, you will sweat a lot and have lots of fun doing exercise, this is the best exercise you can get whether you have boxing skills or not. I have some boxing skills taught from my grandpa and if you have, you will enjoy this game more because there are many areas in this game that applies to the boxing discipline, this is the best VR boxing you get, of course you can always exploit the game and beat the guys easy, as they have their technical limitations, part of the fun in the game is somewhat up to you, how you react and move yourself in the playing field, boxers will try this game and apply like they shadow box on real opponent, casual players will just barage the opponent as many hits as they can, if you are a fan of Fight Night series then this game is the closes VR game to that and of real life boxing.Recommendations- Option to adjust the starting point of your arms (shoulder) It looks closer to my head. Or overall manual calibration.- Improve opponents reaction when doing sidestep, they look dumb when I keep on circling them.- Apply illegal blow warnings (referee warning, kinda) when hitting at the back of the multiple times when playes go behind them.- I don't think the body works well unless we have sensors to detect, leaning forward does not work in this game as your body just moves forward like a hanging slab attached to your neck.- Maybe tweak the damage system to add more damage when countering their punches and less when opponents expect to be attacked or when they are in defensive mode. In real boxing you tend to get hurt more on punches you don't expect.- Maybe try to play with special punches, a charge punch by holding a button to charge it.- Add movement to characters to dodge your attacks, duck, lean way and moving back to lure you to an attack or sidestep and move away when hurt.- Add player knocked down on floor, not following the downed players body because this can cause nausea, maybe just put a downed players body on the floor and add Taunt animation on the characters taunting the downed players body, this will be more challenging and will provoke the players. It would be funny to have the player (John Doe) wearing a VR headset and holding the vive controllers with gloves getting knocked down on the floor.

								The Thrill of the Fight! Is a breakthrough game for VR. Looking at the video and screenshots alone makes you wonder, will this be any good? Well, the answer is YES! This game is phenomenal, and I do not just say it to make it sound good.As soon as you are thrown into it, you get the feel that you are actually there in the training gym. The scale of the players is immensely accurate. Graphics:Graphics are one thing while gameplay is a whole different thing. ToTF has managed to settle truly in between these two things as the visuals are fine the way they are. The players have great details as well as the boxing ring. The only downside I would name is, the background or “Crows” if you can call it, that is a bit lacking at the current release, but hey, that’s not the main focus of the developer at this time.Gameplay:This is where this game truly shines, you are put into a ring to go through 5 opponents (At the time of writing this review) which all vary in personality/skills and size. You immediately raise your guard as you know this will be a fight! This game allows you to do different types of punches such as Jabs, Deflections, Uppercuts and throw straight punches/lunges as well as a sophisticated dodge system which you can combine with Ducking, strafing around your opponent, raising your gloves to guard, but be careful, the side of your head can be open for the opponent to strike, so you really have to managed your blocking, which is great!The enemy AI is a work in progress, but at its current state it is polished enough to be called, more than acceptable! They block, move slightly around the ring and adjust to your play space accordingly. Based on the fighter you face, they might have different abilities. Without spoiling the fights to anyone, think about agility, size, force and weight. Overall, this is a must buy game for anyone, whether they have played boxing before or not. This game will have you sweating after fighting with all the opponents. This promotes an active game style for sure.  The developer is constantly updating the game, on a weekly basis and is delivering new opponents, promised game modes and tweaks to the fighting system. Do yourself a favor and buy this game, you will not regret it as it is pure fun to jab someone in the face, the only thing missing is the feedback of doing so in real life!

Power cap has been removed, opponents move more naturally and fight more dynamically. You can get flash KOs and one punch knockdowns. You can also be taken out very quickly yourself, so you have to think about what you're doing. The game mechanics have been tightened up so it feel a lot more real now, and it's more challenging, although it might still be easy for some (very few) people. You now get blurry vision when damaged which convey the damage really well, and is a good reprentation of being wobbled. Still no rounds but that is coming, and then it will be even better. 								For better explanation of pros/cons, read below.Pros:- Fun- Good workout- Pretty decent AI so far (it says I only have 10 minutes on record, but there's no way - I did four training sessions and fought the first boxer twice, going 1-1).- Does not teach great punching skills, but is great for dodging and timing. Movement depends on your available space.- Innovative use of Vive controller mechanics by changing the grip you use. I was only skeptic for the first five seconds, and then I was sold.- Great for an inde game with probably a low budget.- At full price USD I only paid $10. I can already tell I'm going to be revisiting this often enough to make the dollars/hour spent very cheap.- Actually decent cardio for a game. There's a reason rounds are 3:00 in boxing.Cons:- Training is school of hard knox.- Actual punching skills developed is probably not high.- AI ignores punches if it is in the process of swinging.- AI got right in my face. Not sure if that was intentional, or just the software not reading my position correctly, but given the very strategic nature of the dodge-punch-dodge mechanics, this made even the starting opponent a pain.- Game placed opponent between myself and my PC, which means I was constantly tripping over the headset cord.I used to do American boxing for sport, been in a few matches, got knocked out once with a concussion (it was an unofficial match with gloves and mouth guards, but no headgear - wear your headgear, kids, leave the "no headgear" to the professionals who can afford it). In the last year or so I've switched into other forms of boxing and fighting, but I've let my cardio slide due to injuries and day job volume.This game punished me for it, and I like it. I can still hit a bag for a few rounds, but hitting the empty air is much more tiring. I wouldn't consider it a "simulator," most VR games that attempt to give you a feel for something aren't quite advanced enough, but give it time, I'm sure. The feeling of connecting with a good punch just isn't there. A well-swung roundhouse when your opponent is wide open gets completely ignored if the game was expecting you to block or dodge his slow straight right. The AI registers it was hit by wincing, but continues through with it's action. I suppose otherwise, you could just roll your fists around like patty cake and win every match.That being said, it's a lot of fun and will teach you some boxing fundamentals, I just wish there was more of a tutorial. If you dodge too early, your opponent will change direction and still hit you. Dodge too late, and obviously you still get hit. This is where it shines in the realm of "actual boxing." It took me a few practice sessions to understand what it was doing.EDIT: Forgot to mention the AI getting in my face - again, this is a game, not a simulation, but in that type of situation, you would go for body shots or lock up and look for an opportunity to deliver quick jabs/hooks until my opponent backed off. AI does *not* care, and will throw almost impossible punches that should slip by you instead of nailing you in the face. If you're almost forehead-to-forehead with someone, and they throw a full-shoulder straight right, a slight dodge of the head and it will blow past your ear, over your shoulder, and leave them exposed for a counter-hook. Half-step back, bam. Not here. Admitting this is not a simulation, the game needs AI that recognizes appropriate distance based on height and head position, and react accordingly. I'm 6'0", dev, if you read this and that helps. I did not cheat at the weigh-in (which records your height, apparently) by lowering or raising myself.Also as I mentioned above as a con, the game decided my opponent would be in the direction of my PC. That meant the cord fell right next to my legs, which made dodging very difficult. I appreciate the fact that when I did successfully side-step, the AI followed.All-in-all, I think the game successfully sets out to do what it intends to do - be a fun boxing game, not a sim, not a training tool. While those features would be very cool, for $10, I can't complain at all. I've spent a lot more than that on lessons, books, and gym time, and while this doesn't offer the same benefit - because it's a game and not a simulation - it has definite merit, and is a great workout.

								Boxing capitalizes on the strengths of the Vive while minimizing its weaknesses.  In its 7th update, TotF has progressed from its humble origins into a legitimate game, rather than a promising tech demo.  There is a solid core experience with different enemy styles. If you have a large enough VR space, you can use footwork effectively.TotF is one of the best-designed games available for the Vive currently. Early Access Review
								Great game, lots of fun and very rewarding. You feel like a total boss when you finally knock someone out that you were originally struggling to beat. I think the realism factor also depends alot on how you play, i.e. squaring up and using proper technique instead of trying to find blind spots or glitches with the opponent's AI. The developer is adding content fairly frequently, and seems pretty responsive to the community. The game is also a great workout. Just a couple of things to be aware of:* You'll want a pretty large play area. The game is fairly dependant on mobility (steping, ducking, weaving). When you are backing onto the edge of your playspace, there is no warning system other than the VIVE chaperone.* Use the straps on your tracked controllers and tighten your headstrap. It is really easy to get immersed in the game and forget you're wearing $1400 (AUD) worth of headgear. More than a few times, a swift duck nearly caused the thing to fly right off my head.Despite that, I highly recommend this game.
